body_html:
I suspect the problem is that, when you run the result of bazel build, the resulting binary uses a newly-compiled version of TensorFlow that has whatever compilation options you specify in the build command. By default, bazel will build a CPU-only version, and you need to specify --config=cuda to get a GPU version.

Can you try the following commands instead?

$ bazel build --config=cuda //tensorflow/examples/tutorials/mnist:mnist_with_summaries
$ bazel-bin/tensorflow/examples/tutorials/mnist/mnist_with_summaries
body_text:
I suspect the problem is that, when you run the result of bazel build, the resulting binary uses a newly-compiled version of TensorFlow that has whatever compilation options you specify in the build command. By default, bazel will build a CPU-only version, and you need to specify --config=cuda to get a GPU version.
Can you try the following commands instead?
$ bazel build --config=cuda //tensorflow/examples/tutorials/mnist:mnist_with_summaries
$ bazel-bin/tensorflow/examples/tutorials/mnist/mnist_with_summaries
body:
I suspect the problem is that, when you run the result of `bazel build`, the resulting binary uses a newly-compiled version of TensorFlow that has whatever compilation options you specify in the build command. By default, `bazel` will build a CPU-only version, and you need to specify `--config=cuda` to get a GPU version.

Can you try the following commands instead?

```
$ bazel build --config=cuda //tensorflow/examples/tutorials/mnist:mnist_with_summaries
$ bazel-bin/tensorflow/examples/tutorials/mnist/mnist_with_summaries
```
